did.physloc: Portions of the collection are located offsite; two days notice required for retrieval.
did.abstract: Gerontologist; series in collection include: Biography and Early Career; Lectures, Speeches, Publications; History of Gerontology; Correspondence; Gerontology Research Center Files; Conferences; Foundations; International Association of Gerontology (IAG); International Organizations; Gerontological Society of America; Other Organizations; Audio tapes; and Photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers of Nathan W. Shock were transferred from the Institute of Gerontology, University of Michigan (donor no. 6160) in 1989, 1990, and 1991.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been assigned to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Nathan W. Shock Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Nathan Wetherill Shock, a renowned gerontologist, was born in Lafayette, Indiana on December 25, 1906, the son of Blanche Vandelia Stults, a grade school teacher, and Joseph Henry Shock, a teacher of mathematics, high school principal, and later professor of mathematics at Purdue University. Nathan Shock grew up in Lafayette, received a degree in chemical engineering from Purdue in 1926, and the master's degree in organic chemistry the following year. In 1928 Shock married Margaret B. Truman, a Lafayette resident. In 1930 Shock received a Ph.D. in physiological psychology at the University of Chicago and stayed on as a research associate in the pediatrics department while teaching physiology for two years.

In 1932 Shock went to the University of California, Berkeley, as research associate in the Institute of Child Welfare and assistant professor in physiology, staying until 1941. It was at Berkeley that he learned the value of performing longitudinal studies of humans to assess changes over time in a group of 100 boys and girls who were followed from age 10 to 18 years. Measurement of physiologic changes in infants at the University of Chicago became measurement of changes in adolescents at the University of California, and at the Gerontology Research Center in Baltimore became measurement of physiologic change over time in groups of elderly subjects.

The United States National Institutes of Health (NIH) at Bethesda, Maryland began its interest in aging studies in 1940, and in October of 1941 Shock was called to head the new gerontology unit, with a research facility within the Baltimore City Hospitals. In the late 1940s NIH organized its research programs as institutes with category labels, and the Section on Aging became first a part of the National Heart Institute, was transferred to the National Institute of Child Health and Development and in 1975 the gerontology program became part of the National Institute on Aging; Dr. Shock was named Scientific Director of the new institute and continued his research studies until his retirement in 1977. Then, as Scientist Emeritus, he continued his studies and writings until his death on November 12, 1989 at the age of 82.

Nathan Shock, a man of great organizational abilities, was instrumental in the development and growth of major gerontological societies nationally and internationally. He served as president of the Gerontological Society of America (1960-1961), president of the International Association of Gerontology (1969 to 1972), and editor-in-chief of the Journal of Gerontology.

His most notable contribution to the emerging discipline of gerontology was in the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging. The author of several books, he also contributed more than 200 articles to the scientific literature on gerontology. He was the recipient of numerous awards and honors in his chosen field. Many characterized Nathan Shock as the father of American gerontology.
Dr. Shock had a keen interest in the history of gerontology and sought to preserve the important documents of the field in his papers.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Nathan Wetherill Shock, with bulk dates of 1927 to 1988, measure fifty linear feet. They are divided into thirteen series: Biography and Early Career; Lectures, Speeches, Publications; History of Gerontology; Correspondence; Gerontology Research Center Files; Conferences; Foundations; International Association of Gerontology (IAG); International Organizations-Other; Gerontological Society of America (GSA); Other Organizations; Photographs; and Audio Tapes.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Aging.
Gerontology.
controlaccess.corpname: National Institutes of Health (U. S.). Center for Aging Research.

scopecontent.p: Biography and Early Career (2.5 linear feet) covers the personal life, education, and early professional appointments of Shock. Here, also, is included information on honors and awards from his long career. The first folder contains transcripts of interviews and his autobiographies; these are helpful to the researcher in assessing his philosophy about gerontology, and for his articulate descriptions of the development of aging research within the federal government.

scopecontent.p: Dr. Shock assembled most of the material in the series History of Gerontology (2.5 linear feet) and additional material was added during processing. Shock's writings on the history of gerontology are included here. His long-standing interest in preserving archival material is evidenced in the early folders of this series.

scopecontent.p: The series Correspondence (4 linear feet) is arranged alphabetically and covers the years 1934 to 1988; for unknown reasons it is heavily concentrated in the period of the mid-1970s just before his retirement from the National Institute on Aging. Other useful correspondence is found in such series as International Association of Gerontology.

scopecontent.p: The Gerontology Research Center, an active research facility under the National Institutes of Health, was headed by Shock from 1941 to 1978, at the Baltimore City Hospitals. The arrangement of this series is largely chronological or topical where required for clarity. An important subseries here is the papers of the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging (3 linear feet); it includes information on the recruitment of the first patient into the study in 1957 until the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the study in 1988.

scopecontent.p: In the Foundations series (1.5 linear feet) the files pertaining to the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation are of the most interest. The Macy Foundation is credited with fathering the study of aging through its sponsorship of The Club for Research on Aging (1940-1953), and for interesting the National Institutes of Health in beginning the aging research program within the federal government.

scopecontent.p: The next series is that of the International Association of Gerontology (4 linear feet) covering the period from its founding in 1950 to 1989. Dr. Shock was president of the group from 1966 to 1969 and was in charge of its 8th International Congress, held in Washington, D.C. in August 1969. The records are most comprehensive for this period of the Association.

did.unittitle: The International Association of Gerontology-A Chronicle from 1950-1986, By N.W. Shock

scopecontent.p: The series, International Organizations-Other, (0.5 linear feet) covers the period 1956-1982, and for the most part, represents those meetings in which Shock took part.

World Assembly on the Aged, Vienna

scopecontent.p: The series, Gerontological Society of America(GSA) (5 linear feet), is a detailed record of the Society from its beginning in 1946 to 1988. Dr. Shock was an active participant in the work of the Society throughout his long career and there is much here that contributes to an understanding of the growth of the discipline of gerontology as well as the contribution the Society made to the field.

scopecontent.p: The Other Organizations series (3.5 linear feet) is an alphabetically arranged file of organizations with which Dr. Shock was associated in the period of the 1940s to the 1980s; in many cases he served as a consultant or on the advisory board of such groups as the American Psychological Association, Loyal Order of the Moose, and the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission.

scopecontent.p: There are more than 200 photographs in the series Photographs, divided in two subseries, Personal and Professional. Most are labeled and Shock provided an index to these which may be found in the first folder of the series. Each is numbered and the total group covers the period 1901-1983.

scopecontent.p: The last series, Audio Tapes, numbers approximately 200 tapes in 6 linear feet. Some are labeled. They appear to be tapes of meetings and conferences, but may have little substantive value.
